div.head: Introductory Essay on Childhood, Precocity, and Juvenilia
div.p: In the later nineteenth century, there appears to have arisen an increased interest in the childhoods and juvenilia of “modern”—that is, high Victorian authors.

AsCommodification tied to sentiment in Collingwood owing to the essentially aesthetic orientation of his editing, and that's because of the view of childhood as pristine, described in "Note."
The early writings of Mr. Ruskin were carefully preserved by his parents, who encouraged, though they do not seem to have supervised, the production of his juvenile attempts. In only two or three instances a word has been crossed out, and an emendation substituted by his father; but in several places his father and mother have inserted dates into the note-books, or endorsed a loose sheet "John's Poetry (Date)." There is no trace of subsequent revision on the aauthor's part of any poems, except those which actually appeared in print during his youth. As the editors of the Library Edition would later point out, this portrayal of the early manuscripts is misleading. Collingwood's view of the evidence was overborne, however, by a desire to see the juvenilia as both perfect in its "beautifully written . . . 'copperplate' or 'print' hand" and "spontaneous . . . almost improvisational" in invention. The mixture of sentiment and ownership in Collingwood's metaphors, shown earlier, is a logical outcome of an aesthetic view of childhood and juvenilia, readily joined to a bio-bibliographical approach to understanding authorship, yet, by virtue of that view of childhood, resistant to any taint of the commodification with which the editorial and bookmaking approach is nonetheless involved.
See note on Shepherd re. contradiction between Atheneaum's espousal of author's authority, and its sentement for childhood.

While collectors and author societies were keen to explore authors' childhoods, as evident in the venue for Axon's bibliography, the Manchester Literary Society, whose publications included numerous studies of other authors' boyhoods, this "bio-bibliographical" approach clashed with the editorial authority maintained by many Victorian writers, such as Tennyson and Browning, who suppressed juvenilia in particular and who discouraged a genetic approach to their works in general. The bio-bibliographical approach, encouraged by collecting, combined with a view of authors' juvenilia (especially Ruskin's) as pristine, textually free of revision or need of emendation, and representable through an essentially aesthetic orientation to editing.

In the early nineteenth century, the interest in juvenilia as such appears to have been a private concern of families. As W. G. Collingwood remarks, John James and Margaret Ruskin treasured virtually everything that they and their son wrote during his youth (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:262; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:261). Authors themselves took a more equivocal view of their early work. Ruskin resented his fatherʼs preoccupation with his early poetry at the very time when the writer, in the preparation for Stones of Venice (1850, 1853), was crucially defining himself more as a critic than as a poetic prose writer. Yet, at the same time, in Modern Painters III (1854), Ruskin adopted a Wordsworthian approach to history by taking his own development from childhood as an example of modern landscape sensibility. Robert Browning, whose boyhood shared so many influences with Ruskinʼs in the semirural lanes and evangelical chapels of Camberwell, was more reticent, destroying nearly everything of importance in connection with his early writing. Leigh Hunt. . . . The Brontës .

As a result, Ruskinʼs early literary development has been as admired and extensively documented and studied as that of the Brontës, while Browningʼs biographers have been forced to rely on more indirect sources (see Maynard). Yet, whereas Browning, having disposed of the evidence, proved surprisingly insouciant in the ultimate testamentary arrangements for his literary estate (see Millgate), Ruskin and his later circle of editors and secretaries at Brantwood were as cautious as Browning, if not as destructive, about the impression posterity would form of his early writing. Their measures persist through the still standard editions, W. G. Collingwoodʼs 1891 edition of the Poems, and E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburnʼs 1903–12 Library Edition of Ruskinʼs Works; and, despite monumental corrective editing by Helen Gill Viljoen (much of which remains unpublished), James S. Dearden, and Van Akin Burd, the earlier bibliographies and editions continue profoundly to influence how the early Ruskin has been read. Fortunately, it is characteristic of Ruskin that, while he and his circle guarded how his writing should be approached, apparently nothing of the early writing—unlike the later correspondence with Rose LaTouche—was deliberately committed to flame. The purpose of this edition is to compile the first comprehensive and reliable descriptive bibliography and chronology of the early Ruskin manuscripts and to publish what Ruskinʼs first editors excluded from their editions.

Even now, the dispersal of the early manuscripts forces reliance on the earlier editions, with all their bibliographic errors and questionable editorial policies by Collingwood and Cook and Wedderburn. More recent scholars, such as Burd and Dearden, have overcome the early editorsʼ influence to compile reliable editions of selected portions of the early writing. Until now, however, no comprehensive bibliographic reconsideration of the entirety of the early manuscripts has been made available. Only by means of a comprehensively revised chronology and descriptive bibliography, which form the foundation of this edition, can we at last fully understand the later mythologizing of Ruskinʼs childhood and, behind that, the actual youthful writing in all the complexity of its genius.

Cook and Wedderburn must be given credit for correcting at least part of the story about Ruskinʼs first publication, since, by their time, the mythologized transmission of Ruskinʼs early writing had already begun, influencing its treatment by the first bibliographers and editors. In the 1870s, in his Catalogue of the Rudimentary Series of drawings at the Oxford schools, and in Deucalion, Ruskin confidently—even with colorful supporting anecdotes—attributed his first appearance in print to prose publications, his two 1834 papers for Loudonʼs Magazine of Natural History (Works, 21:243, 26:275; nos. 190–91). In the 1870s, in context of his writing on drawing, botany, and geology, Ruskin very likely wanted to believe his first publications to have been scientific and factual, rather than poetic, in nature. Ruskinʼs faulty memory or wishful thinking soon became “fact,” however, when his first major bibliographers, Shepherd (9) and Wise (1:302–3, 2:111), depended on Ruskinʼs remarks to award the distinction of his debut to the 1834 papers for Loudonʼs Magazine. So settled became the prejudice that even Collingwood—who ought to have known better, since he discovered John Jamesʼs entry in MS IV on the Spiritual Times publication and even printed it, without comment, in 1891 (PJR, 1:264)—persisted in heading a chronological list of Ruskinʼs publications with the Magazine of Natural History papers. In his 1893 Life of Ruskin, Collingwood maintained that Ruskin “began his literary career” as the “analytic John Ruskin . . . already an enfant terrible” of prose argument (1:233, 49–50).

Before the last decades of the century, when Ruskin and his editors summoned faulty bibliography in support of a desired story about the young natural scientist, John James, in the middle of the century, told his own story through selection for the Poems by “J.R.” The pencil scoring through John Jamesʼs mistaken entry in MS IV may indicate, not that somebody in the family spotted its inaccuracy, but that the father had decided, curiously, not to include his sonʼs very first publications—not even the 1830 “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water,” which John James certainly remembered. Instead, he opened the volume with “Song” (“I weary for the torrent leaping,” no. 176), a previously unpublished poem of 1833 (misdated 1832 by Collingwood). Why did John James choose this manuscript poem, and not the printed “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water,” when an otherwise pervasive principle of selection in the 1850 Poems was to reprint poems that had already been published? We may never know, since the fifty copies of the 1850 Poems constituted a private and very personal enterprise by John James, limited to circulation among family and friends; however, a suggestive fact about the 1833 poem has emerged from the revised chronology. This is one of the few poems Ruskin wrote in early 1833, when Margaret finally prevailed in enforcing a ban on the boyʼs poetic composition (“My harp is sunk to rest,” the poem laments), and in redirecting his energies into the Sermon Books (see nos. 176, 170)—a verdict to which the father, probably reluctantly, assented. Two decades later, in retrieving this poem to open his collection, was John James belatedly repealing the old prohibition, tenderly restoring the silenced harp to his son? Ruskin, in Venice at the time and engaged in repudiating his adolescent Byronism, no longer wanted the harp (Helsinger, Ruskin and the Art of the Beholder 140–63). The additional ironies revealed by the revised dating and circumstances of the 1833 poem tend to reinforce the view that, in compiling the Poems of 1850, John James was living in the past; however, the facts also point unexpectedly to the fatherʼs solicitude for his sonʼs feelings and resentments—if ironically and irrelevantly outdated ones.
